stories.headline: Gaps for Grads
stories.summary: Some top students in the class of 2024 share their experiences about how well Houston ISD prepared them for college. While some thrived despite a lack of preparation, others felt the opportunities available to them were limited, reflecting mixed outcomes within the district's education programs.

stories.headline: A Look at Key Bills That Passed, Failed
stories.summary: The 89th legislative session saw mixed results with some key bills passing while others failed. Lawmakers filed many bills this session, but only a small percentage passed, impacting various aspects of policy and governance. The report highlights some notable political failures alongside successes this year.

stories.headline: At This A&M Lab, There Will Be Blood
stories.summary: Texas A&M scientist Zach Adelman explores the complexities and ethical concerns of studying viruses, emphasizing the importance of understanding mosquito behavior in combating diseases. Adelman discusses the difficulties involved in research including handling mosquitoes and the necessity of such studies for advancing science.

stories.headline: Economic Slide Stirs Recipe for Disaster
stories.summary: The Houston dining scene faces challenges as economic uncertainty pressures small restaurants. Industry leaders express concern over the impact of an uncertain economy on the survival of local businesses amid rising costs and past financial hardships, highlighting the precarious situation for restaurants in the city.

stories.headline: No Papers, No Path
stories.summary: After 23 years in the United States, a Colombian family's American life unravels, highlighting the challenges immigrants face regarding legal status, fear, discrimination, confusion over the U.S. travel ban, and local leaders' criticism of the travel restrictions affecting immigrants from Haiti, Venezuela, and Cuba.

stories.headline: Legendary lineages: Have the Panthers’ joined South Florida’s sports dynasties from the past?
stories.summary: The Florida Panthers, with a strong history and recent success including a trip to the Stanley Cup Final, are being compared to iconic South Florida sports teams from the past. The article discusses the Panthers' rise, their passionate fanbase, and the legacy they are building, with insights from team manager Bill Zito and players.

stories.headline: President: National Guard will help quell LA protests
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is deploying 2,000 California National Guard troops over objections to Los Angeles protests related to immigration authorities. The White House stated the deployment addresses lawlessness in California, although California Governor Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, opposed the move, saying it would escalate tensions. Protests extended into a second day with tear gas and confrontations involving Border Patrol personnel.

stories.headline: Coal, gas plants slated for closure reprieved by Trump
stories.summary: A 63-year-old coal-fired plant scheduled for permanent closure in Michigan was ordered by President Trump to stay open as part of a broader plan to boost fossil fuels under a national energy emergency. The emergency orders surprised companies operating such plants, with some retirees delaying plans. The Michigan Public Service Commission is assessing costs of the order while some Democratic officials expressed concern about challenges to the coal plant's restart.

stories.headline: Hospitality group forms political arm
stories.summary: The Greater Chattanooga Hospitality Association is forming a political action committee to support elected officials favoring the tourism and hospitality sector, a major employer in Hamilton County. The new PAC aims to give a voice to local politics and is seen as a tool to boost tourism, timed with reconsiderations on how best to fund tourism promotion. The initiative is backed by local leaders hoping to strengthen the local tourism economy.

stories.headline: Big bill tackles overtime tax cuts
stories.summary: A new bill addresses the complexities of President Trump's proposal on 'no tax on overtime,' focusing on whether workers over 40 hours a week would get tax breaks. Republicans are pushing this bill through the House and Senate, limiting the tax break to Americans paid at time-and-a-half rates for work exceeding 40 hours a week. Critics and supporters debate if the tax break will reshape the American labor market, with concerns over potential drawbacks on wages and employment.

stories.headline: Last Act
stories.summary: Jeff Chelesvig, the only Tony voter in Iowa, will retire after 30 years leading Des Moines Performing Arts. He has brought Broadway hits such as 'Hamilton,' 'The Lion King,' 'Phantom of the Opera,' and most recently '& Juliet' to Des Moines.

stories.headline: Judge dismisses Metlakatla murder charge, saying police badly botched the case
stories.summary: A judge in Ketchikan dismissed a murder charge against a Metlakatla man accused of killing his brother, citing significant errors by the local police department in investigating and prosecuting the case. The dismissal with prejudice means the case is permanently closed, which has sparked criticism of the police and prosecutorial process in Alaska's only tribal reservation. The decision highlights issues of law enforcement mishandling in high-profile homicide cases.

stories.headline: Trump races to fix a big mistake: DOGE fired too many people
stories.summary: The Trump administration is scrambling to rehire federal employees who were fired or forced to resign under the DOGE staff-slashing initiative. This includes many workers from the Food and Drug Administration and other agencies, which saw substantial staffing disruptions earlier this spring. The administration is trying to remedy the fallout after facing criticism for abruptly cutting federal staff amid ongoing government operations and public health needs.

stories.headline: Kilmar Abrego Garcia is back in the US, charged with human smuggling
stories.summary: After being mistakenly deported to El Salvador, Kilmar Abrego Garcia has returned to the US and faces charges of human smuggling. He allegedly smuggled hundreds of people across the country including members of the violent MS-13 gang. Abrego Garcia and his lawyers plan a different defense, highlighting his difficult past and family background. The case illustrates ongoing challenges in immigration enforcement and deportations within the US.

stories.headline: Public assistance office keeps Alaskans waiting
stories.summary: Proposed work rules for Medicaid and SNAP could increase the backlog at Alaska's Division of Public Assistance. Many people, including those with mental health conditions, are waiting hours, sometimes in harsh weather, to get assistance. The division operates only one site in Anchorage, expecting applicants to visit offices in person to avoid a backlog. The situation has left many Alaskans without access to needed benefits, worsening their circumstances.

stories.headline: BIG CHEESE: How paneer became a booming business here
stories.summary: The story explores how the rise of paneer, an Indian specialty, has become a booming business in Whatcom County through a cross-cultural and cross-border tale involving immigrant communities. It highlights the journey of Appel Farms and Nanak Foods in producing and distributing paneer across U.S. markets, showcasing the interconnectedness of Indian immigrants and regional economies.

stories.headline: Long waits for streetlight fixes irritate residents
stories.summary: Residents have reported long waiting times for streetlight repairs and local authorities have been prompted to address these concerns when a man used his son's bullet-torn car seat to get the city council's attention. Despite the attention, some streetlights remain non-functional, causing safety concerns and increasing the risk of late-night disturbances in the neighborhood.

stories.headline: State providing minimal treatment for people committed to McNeil Island for sex offenses
stories.summary: The Department of Social and Health Services is providing minimal treatment, just two hours of weekly group treatment, for residents at a secure facility for sex offenders on McNeil Island. Reviews show the facility fails to meet its own treatment standards, with inadequate access to mental health care and limited treatment hours, raising concerns about the effectiveness of rehabilitation efforts.

stories.headline: NASA and Pentagon make push for SpaceX alternatives
stories.summary: NASA and Pentagon officials have accelerated efforts to develop alternative rockets and spacecraft to SpaceX following threats from President Trump to cancel SpaceX contracts. The move aims to reduce dependency on SpaceX for critical government space missions and highlights concerns over the company's control of space operations and sensitive satellite launches.

stories.headline: 10 Grads to Watch
stories.summary: This month, thousands of young people across Maine are celebrating their high school graduations. This year's standout seniors include top scholars, athletes, musicians, artists, social activists, immigrants, and future professionals such as a plumber in training, a technology whiz, filmmaker, and future physician. These graduates have overcome significant challenges including language and cultural barriers, family crises, and insecurities. Their intended career paths span law, politics, business, advocacy, counseling, government, advertising, and public health. They have already achieved much and are anticipated to continue accomplishing great things in the future.

stories.headline: How a former lawmaker grew weed with alleged Chinese crime groups
stories.summary: Eddie DuGay, a former Democratic legislator, appeared before the Turner Board of Selectmen in October 2020 seeking permits to grow medical marijuana inside a warehouse on Conant Road. Investigations have revealed his cannabis business was linked to a web of shell companies and illegal grows tied to alleged Chinese crime groups. The warehouse quickly became a center for organized crime laundering money through illegal cannabis operations, according to state investigators. The case highlights the dangers of illicit cannabis grows in Maine and the involvement of transnational criminal organizations.

stories.headline: Contractor accused of defrauding church in school building project
stories.summary: Stephen K. Halford is accused of forging invoices to deceive Holy Trinity Lutheran Church & School in South Tampa out of at least $674,000, according to authorities. The fraud was related to fundraising for a new building to house the church's middle school due to growth needs. Halford's company, HV Contracting, was supposed to demolish an old building and erect a new one, but court records reveal issues including a budget discrepancy of over $1 million. Investigations were triggered by troubling discoveries, leading to a lawsuit and criminal probe by Tampa police. The church leadership has worked to get the project back on track.

stories.headline: She reviewed a restaurant on Yelp. Then came a lawsuit
stories.summary: Irene Eng wrote a 795-word Yelp review about her dining experience at Hales Blackbrick, a popular Tampa Asian restaurant, criticizing the quality. After posting the review, the restaurant owner sent her a cease-and-desist letter and later filed a lawsuit. The legal battle, which was eventually dismissed, highlights the tense relationship between chefs, restaurant owners, and their customers over online reviews and business reputation. Despite the conflict, Eng expects to continue writing about her food experiences in Florida.

stories.headline: As Epic Universe draws hype, what's next for Tampa's hometown park?
stories.summary: Busch Gardens, predating Disney World and Universal, is facing competition as Universal Orlando opens Epic Universe. Busch Gardens invested $70 million in a new attraction and improvements to remain competitive. However, experts say Busch Gardens caters more to locals while Disney and Universal attract tourists with broader appeal and resources. Families may choose their destinations based on varied preferences. Epic Universe aims to become a weeklong destination for tourists with attractions, sets, and studios not available elsewhere. The theme park is adjusting to maintain visitor interest amid rising competition in Florida's theme park landscape.

stories.headline: Venture capitalists ramping up investment in L.A. area
stories.summary: Diverse venture capital firms, including those focused beyond artificial intelligence, have increased their investments in the Los Angeles area, drawing $3.1 billion in first-quarter deals, a 15% rise from last year. The surge is supported by companies like Blackstone, DDN, and others that drive private equity and technological investments, aiming to spur growth in AI, self-driving cars, and related sectors.

stories.headline: Swelling threat from quakes
stories.summary: California faces a serious threat from near-shore tsunamis triggered by earthquakes close to the coast. Experts warn that such tsunamis could devastate coastal communities, with waves potentially reaching the Los Angeles area. There is concern about the state's preparedness to issue timely emergency alerts and manage the looming natural disaster risk.

stories.headline: Mexico’s lawsuit didn’t succeed but forced U.S. to face gun traffic issue
stories.summary: More than a decade ago, Mexican authorities put up a billboard along the border highlighting the problem of firearms crossing into Mexico. Although the lawsuit seeking a $10 billion settlement against U.S. gunmakers did not succeed, it brought attention to the issue of gun trafficking and violence fueled by firearms flowing through the border, sparking a broader discussion on the matter.

stories.headline: ICE raids across L.A. spur protests
stories.summary: Immigration and Customs Enforcement carried out aggressive raids across Los Angeles, leading to protests and clashes with local community members. The Trump administration deployed the National Guard to assist with the operations. Local leaders and migrant advocates have pushed back against the raids, with California's governor condemning the actions and emphasizing the need to keep peace amid chaos.

stories.headline: Ruling: Colleges can pay athletes
stories.summary: A federal judge approved a NCAA settlement that allows colleges to pay their athletes, marking a significant change by shredding the last vestiges of the amateur model. This ruling clears the way for schools to begin paying athletes millions of dollars starting next month, benefiting thousands of former players and those at the college level.

stories.headline: President: Fallout for Musk could be 'serious'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is not backing off his battle with Elon Musk, stating he has no desire to repair their relationship and warning of "serious consequences" if Musk tries to help Democrats in upcoming elections. Trump commented after NBC's Kristen Welker's interview and also issued a warning to certain lawmakers and candidates who may support opposition parties.

stories.headline: Sovereignty wins Belmont by beating Journalism
stories.summary: Sovereignty and jockey Junior Alvarado won the Belmont Stakes after a delay caused by heavy downpours which dried up before the start of the race. The victory highlights Sovereignty's strength on the racing track and junior’s skillful ride.

stories.headline: Pittman eyes Maryland Democratic Party chair
stories.summary: Maryland Democratic Party Chair Ken Ulman announced plans to resign by June 13, and Anne Arundel County Executive Steuart Pittman is considering running for the position. This development indicates a key leadership change within the Maryland Democratic Party.

stories.headline: Regular rolling blackouts may become reality in Md.
stories.summary: Maryland may face regular rolling blackouts if the state experiences a lack of adequate energy supply during peak demand times. This possibility is due to undersupplied energy capacity according to BGE. Such blackouts could affect Baltimore-area residents and prove challenging to manage in the coming years.

stories.headline: ‘Don’t Just Sue Them, Snyder Them!’: A slogan still 'worth its weight in gold'
stories.summary: Stephen L. Snyder, a renowned personal injury attorney once called for jurors to use the phrase "Don’t Just Sue Them, Snyder Them!" with the aim of achieving justice. He said the government and Snyder have a dishonest way of dealing with cases but the slogan remains a popular community phrase symbolizing resistance and determination to seek justice effectively.

stories.headline: Disastrous oil spills in 1970, ’75 among dozen to have affected Harbor
stories.summary: The long-term effects of the recent 5,000-gallon oil spill in Baltimore Harbor are still unknown. Historical data shows that multiple oil spills occurred in the harbor over decades, with the 1970s seeing some of the worst incidents including a 1975 spill from the largest oil barge and a 1970 spill that emptied thousands of gallons of oil. These past spills caused significant damage and impacted local wildlife and environments.

stories.headline: Evaporation, cleanup could contain damage
stories.summary: A 5,000-gallon oil spill in Baltimore Harbor’s Harbor East neighborhood is being handled with a cleanup effort expected to limit long-term environmental damage. Experts say most of the spilled diesel is likely to evaporate quickly and efforts to contain the spill using booms and cleanup tactics are underway. Officials remain concerned about the amount of diesel that entered the water and are monitoring closely.

stories.headline: ‘They’re going after everybody’
stories.summary: The landlord said he has rented out two rooms in a home he owns in Highlandtown, making $1,200 per month from these tenants. However, ice agents are increasing enforcement in Baltimore, including pinning a black vehicle in a pavement outside a home and arresting several tenants. The landlord states the raids are creating fear among the community and disrupting lives, as ICE has arrested five confirmed tenants so far.

stories.headline: A Star Is Born
stories.summary: The Michelin awards could boost the local economy by enhancing the restaurant scene in the area. This story explores the potential economic impact and opportunities that the prestigious Michelin awards may bring to local restaurants and the wider community.

stories.headline: Bullet train to drive profit
stories.summary: A new study commissioned by the Dallas City Council projects that the Dallas-to-Houston bullet train will significantly boost the economy, potentially generating an average annual gain of $5 billion and creating over 28,000 jobs in the region from 2029 to 2050. While the data is promising, some local leaders remain skeptical about realizing the predicted benefits, especially after the U.S. Department of Transportation, under the Trump administration, canceled a $63.9 million grant for the project due to concerns about ballooning project costs, putting taxpayers at risk.

stories.headline: Southern Baptists look ahead
stories.summary: The Southern Baptist Convention, the largest Protestant denomination in the United States, is holding its annual meeting in Dallas after several years. This year's gathering at the Kay Bailey Hutchison Convention Center expects between 18,000 to 20,000 attendees and includes resource fairs, training sessions, and keynote events. The convention reflects on past controversies regarding sexual abuse within the denomination but is moving forward focusing on unity and future leadership. North American Mission Board members played active roles during the event, emphasizing community and support.

stories.headline: What’s next on Abbott’s list?
stories.summary: Governor Greg Abbott, after a significant legislative session focusing on school vouchers and other legacy-defining bills, is expected to continue pushing his agenda through 2026 and beyond. Abbott, now Texas’ longest-serving governor, has gained substantial political influence with strong support from Americans for Prosperity and remains a key figure in the 2028 Republican presidential race, potentially benefiting from reelection efforts and his alignment with President Donald Trump. His legislative priorities aim to shape Texas' future prominently.

stories.headline: Then the screams began
stories.summary: A devastating tornado with 170 mph winds struck parts of Laurel and Pulaski counties in Southern Kentucky, causing widespread destruction and killing at least 20 people. Despite the tragedy, stories of survival, love, and the determination to rebuild emerge from the affected communities.

stories.headline: Nampa Gateway Center to become the Sugar District
stories.summary: Salt Lake City developer the Gardner Group is attempting a herculean task of revitalizing a shopping mall in 2025 by rebranding the long-declining Nampa Gateway Center as the Sugar District. This renovation includes a new facade, updated landscaping, parking areas, and lighting upgrades. The Sugar District aims to be more than just a shopping center, embodying a 'full revival' with additions like a 112-room TownPlace Suites hotel, a second location for Meridian's The created a vibrant and energetic place, according to managing partner David Wali.

stories.headline: US economy created 139,000 May jobs, higher than expected
stories.summary: The U.S. economy added 139,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in May, surpassing economists' expectations of 125,000 to 130,000 jobs created. The unemployment rate remained steady at 4.2%. While federal employment fell and some sectors saw job cuts, gains in healthcare, leisure, and hospitality contributed to the positive numbers. Despite signs of an uncertain economy with concerns around tariffs and inflation, job growth in May was strong, though the impact of federal job cuts and layoff battles may surface in future economic data.

stories.headline: No punishment, no crime: Is flying a Pride flag illegal or not?
stories.summary: Boise's new city law regarding flying pride flags outside Boise City Hall has stirred discussion on whether it is illegal or not. Despite an Idaho law banning most flags on government property, the city of Boise has been flying the Pride flag at City Hall for years. After a recent law took effect, Boise Mayor Lauren McLean maintained the city's right to fly the flag, asserting it is not a crime if it follows city rules. The discussion hinges on legal interpretations and political considerations around regulation of flags on government property.

stories.headline: Boise Democrat Monica Church aims to defy party labels
stories.summary: Rep. Monica Church of Boise, who comes from a family with deep political roots, is serving in the Idaho Legislature after being elected in 2024. She represents District 19 which covers Boise's North End. Church seeks to carry the legacies of her family while navigating the challenges of a divided party and trying to bridge gaps within the Idaho Democratic Party at a time when Democrats are struggling with voter engagement. She has ancestry including a Democratic Idaho Governor and emphasizes a personal and pragmatic approach to politics.

stories.headline: 'We made our dream come true'
stories.summary: Ni Burmese highlights the story of a family business that has realized its dream by capturing the essence of family recipes and offering fresh ingredients, showcasing a success story in the local community.

stories.headline: Sports Week: Sights Set on State Tournament
stories.summary: High school baseball teams in the area are preparing and gearing up for the upcoming state tournament, showcasing their best players and evaluating their chances for the playoffs.

stories.headline: The Underwater Lawn Mower
stories.summary: Researchers are using a specialized machine, weighing 1,100 pounds, to remove invasive mussels from the bottom of Lake Michigan, aiming to protect the aquatic ecosystem from these harmful species.

stories.headline: 'It could happen anywhere'
stories.summary: Arizona cities are preparing after witnessing the devastation caused by the Palisades Fire. The local communities are taking steps to address fire risks and enhance preparedness to prevent such destruction in the future.

stories.headline: Boozman-led committee readying SNAP action
stories.summary: U.S. Senator John Boozman leads a Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee preparing to release legislation regarding SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program). The bill is expected to include new language to help align Congressional representatives on funding and policy for the program, which serves millions of Americans, including 42 million people nationwide and nearly 239,000 in Arkansas. The committee aims to refine the House's approach and provide enhanced guidance on nutrition assistance.

stories.headline: Lobbyist firms report $1.6M spent in state
stories.summary: Lobbyists registered in Arkansas reported spending approximately $1.6 million during the General Assembly's regular session, marking the highest total in 16 years. Advertising and telephone expenses accounted for a significant portion of the spending, with the largest contributions coming from firms working on behalf of the Conservatives for Lower Health Care Costs, Inc. PLUS Communications also reported substantial lobbying expenses. This surge in lobbying expenditures reflects efforts to influence health-related programs and tax policies in Arkansas.

stories.headline: Trump calls up Guard over protest against ICE
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is deploying 2,000 California National Guard troops in response to protests in Los Angeles against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The decision aims to address demonstrations and potential clashes between immigration authorities and protesters. Officials emphasize that the move is meant to maintain order during ongoing contention surrounding immigration enforcement in the state.

stories.headline: Hardin’s capture short on answers
stories.summary: Grant Matthew Hardin was captured after a dramatic escape from prison, but many questions remain about the circumstances of his break out. The 29-year-old, who weighs roughly 259 pounds, is recovering after a physical assessment and fingerprinting at North Central Unit prison. Investigations are ongoing involving local law enforcement, the FBI, and U.S. marshals agencies to understand how the escape happened and if anyone else was involved.

stories.headline: Democrats’ laws seen in crosshairs of Republican bill
stories.summary: Republican lawmakers are targeting key spending and tax provisions enacted by Democrats, especially those passed during President Donald Trump's first term and extended under recent legislation. The GOP aims to curb or repeal programs benefitting low-income and immigrant populations in Arkansas and nationwide, including state-funded initiatives. The political contention highlights ongoing battles over tax breaks, education funding, and other priorities ahead of the next congressional session.

stories.headline: Big Names, Bold Plans
stories.summary: Sacramento State president Luke Wood, director of athletics Mark Orr, and men's basketball coach Mike Bibby are raising the profile of Sacramento State athletics with ambitious plans. They are redesigning The Well to be a new basketball venue for men's and women's basketball, aiming to create a bold new presence for the university's sports programs.

stories.headline: Kansas City employee sues after death threats over Butker post she didn’t write
stories.summary: A Kansas City communications staffer has sued her superiors for ignoring her requests to clear her name after being falsely accused of posting a social media message that doxxed Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker, leading to online harassment including racist and death threats. The city declined comment due to ongoing litigation. The suit highlights concerns over city employee treatment and social media misuse.

stories.headline: Fight for Innocence
stories.summary: Sandra "Sandy" Hemme spent 43 years in prison for a murder she didn't commit. Missouri initially resisted setting her free, but she was released in July 2024, highlighting ongoing issues with wrongful convictions in the state.

stories.headline: How a single night changed one street forever
stories.summary: A deadly plane crash on January 31 involving a medical transport flight bound for Mexico profoundly impacted Rupert Street in Northeast Philadelphia. The plane exploded after crashing into the avenue, killing all six onboard, including an 11-year-old girl, and devastating a local Mount Airy couple whose car was destroyed by flames. The incident caused chaos across multiple blocks, deeply affecting the neighborhood and residents who continue to share their stories.

stories.headline: LGBTQ allies say they need more from Shapiro
stories.summary: LGBTQ advocates in Pennsylvania express frustration with Governor Josh Shapiro's lack of vocal support amid increasing federal attacks on transgender rights and health care access. Despite valuing his support, advocates are urging Shapiro to take a stronger, more vocal stance to combat recent restrictions and discriminatory measures, emphasizing the need for leadership in the face of rising challenges to the LGBTQ community.

stories.headline: Tracking teen offenders, no warrant required
stories.summary: Philadelphia is increasingly tracking teens using GPS technology without requiring warrants, aggressively monitoring their location data to enforce curfews and house arrests. This practice raises concerns over privacy, potential violations of juvenile rights, and the city’s expanding role in surveillance despite constitutional protections. Experts highlight that many monitored teens have not been adjudicated delinquent, underscoring the invasive nature of this initiative.

stories.headline: Musk may be out, but DOGE is advancing
stories.summary: Despite Elon Musk's political setbacks and blowup with President Donald Trump, the DOGE community is advancing by securing federal positions. Several former DOGE members now hold roles in government agencies, including the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency. These insiders continue efforts to dismantle agencies targeted by Trump, demonstrating DOGE's deep integration within the current administration.

stories.headline: U's budget, tuition plans set off alarms
stories.summary: The University of Minnesota's proposed 7% reduction in academic programs and steep tuition hikes have sparked fears among faculty, advisors, and students about affordability and access. Officials announced a 6.5% tuition jump for in-state undergraduates and increased costs for Twin Cities and Rochester campuses. Concerns about funding cuts and increased student debt underline rising tensions surrounding the university's financial planning.

stories.headline: We don't want to lose this mine
stories.summary: Water rising inside the flooded Minorca Mine and the shutdown of Cleveland-Cliffs mines have caused significant fear and economic hardship among Iron Range miners and their families. The layoffs and economic uncertainty are impacting local communities, with residents expressing that the situation feels chaotic and indefinite. The mine, which once ceased operations abruptly in March, symbolizes broader economic challenges facing the region’s mining industry.

stories.headline: Walz confronts rift with labor allies as he mulls run for 3rd term
stories.summary: Governor Tim Walz is facing challenges from labor allies as contract negotiations and budget cuts create tensions. Labor leaders express mixed feelings about Walz's approaches amid ongoing struggles over state worker raises and healthcare funding. With a potential third term looming, Walz seeks to rebuild support while addressing union concerns about contract terms and state budget decisions.

stories.headline: Meth makes dangerous comeback
stories.summary: As the public's attention diverted to the fentanyl crisis, methamphetamine use has surged dangerously in Minnesota. The pattern of drug abuse has shifted to polydrug use, with methamphetamine becoming more prevalent and causing new problems including homelessness. Harm reduction leaders highlight that while meth use has surpassed fentanyl in some ways, it hasn't yet garnered the same level of public awareness or legal attention.

stories.headline: Chicago's Kid Carjackers
stories.summary: A detailed report explores the yearslong crime spree of the SRT Boys crew in Chicago. The story highlights their activities including carjackings and points to social media posts where the group flaunted weapons and cash. This piece is part of the Watchdogs series investigating violence trends in the city.

stories.headline: Why is Chicago violence plummeting? Some credit street outreach workers
stories.summary: An analysis focusing on the decline in violence in Chicago attributes some of the success to efforts by street outreach workers who engage with at-risk populations to prevent violence. This feature looks into community efforts making an impact within the city.

stories.headline: Business picks up for Chicago's secondhand stores in the wake of Trump's trade war
stories.summary: In the aftermath of trade tensions sparked by Trump's trade war, Chicago's secondhand stores are experiencing increased business. The article covers the economic shifts benefiting these stores and how local entrepreneurs are adapting to the changing market conditions.

stories.headline: Researchers worry as Trump cuts slash cancer, HIV studies in MI
stories.summary: Michigan public health leaders express concern over federal spending cuts under President Donald Trump, which have impacted cancer and HIV research and other health services. These cuts include revocations of COVID-19-related grants, causing disruptions at regional labs, community clinics, and affecting efforts to control infectious diseases.

stories.headline: Free pre-K creating 'unintended' problems
stories.summary: Michigan families are facing challenges with summer child care due to the state's 4-year-olds falling into a difficult care limbo. This issue arises as free pre-K programs, including the Great Start Readiness Program (GSRP), expand and limit funding to traditional school year care. Public schools opening GSRP classrooms early have left some parents struggling to find summer care for their children.

stories.headline: Summer fun: Tigers are hot!
stories.summary: The Detroit Tigers have started their summer season strongly, drawing large crowds to Comerica Park in early June. After a slow start in past years, the team remains a central figure in local sports with fans enjoying the games and the summer atmosphere.

stories.headline: PFAS fears lead to more ‘Do Not Eat’ warnings
stories.summary: The state of Michigan has increased the number of 'Do Not Eat' advisories for fish due to elevated levels of toxic PFAS chemicals in lakes and rivers. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services lowered screening thresholds, leading to a tripling of affected water bodies and numerous fish consumption warnings across the state. The advisories have grown because new testing and studies indicate PFAS exposure poses greater health risks than previously understood.

stories.headline: A ‘multibillion-dollar game’ funnels cash to side companies
stories.summary: The article discusses the widespread issue of nursing homes in the United States allegedly funneling millions of dollars meant for care into side businesses they control. This practice has drawn criticism as operators use related entities to blur where funds go, leading to accusations of fraud, waste, and abuse of Medicaid funds. It highlights the challenges in improving care for the elderly while operators focus on financial manipulation, according to reports and advocacy groups.

stories.headline: Secret of S.F. malls that defy doom loop
stories.summary: Rebekah Penaloza and her friend traveled to San Francisco's Japantown to shop for K-pop merchandise, Pokémon cards, and nostalgic anime trinkets. Despite struggles in downtown malls, Japantown and Stonestown thrive, offering shoppers unique experiences. The success of these malls comes from a variety of specialized retailers and community engagement that keeps them alive and vibrant.

stories.headline: Lowell’s 'lottery kids' prove they belong
stories.summary: Data on students at Lowell High School in San Francisco shows that 'lottery kids,' selected through a mostly random process during the pandemic, are performing academically on par with merit-based students. Despite initial skepticism and concerns from parents and teachers, these students have demonstrated their ability to belong and succeed at the elite institution, indicating a relatively small disparity in achievement.

stories.headline: Waymo teaching its driverless taxis human behaviors to better blend in
stories.summary: Waymo is deploying its driverless taxis in San Francisco's Sunset District, where the vehicles mimic human driving behaviors to blend in with urban traffic. The autonomous vehicles are programmed to handle complex interactions at intersections and follow traffic rules with a human-like approach. This advancement aims to improve safety and acceptance of driverless technology in city environments.

stories.headline: Alioto’s to vanish with port changes
stories.summary: Alioto's Restaurant, a classic seafood spot beloved by Bay Area families for nearly 80 years before closing in 2020, is set to be demolished and replaced by a new public plaza as part of a $10 million port redevelopment plan. Port Director Elaine Forbes highlighted the difficulty in preserving the aging landmark due to structural issues, emphasizing the need for modernization despite its historical significance.

stories.headline: An economy pressed from all sides
stories.summary: The region's business model is especially exposed by Trump's policies, impacting various sectors such as education, inflation, energy, and innovation. Higher education faces challenges as cuts and uncertainty affect business activity. Inflation-related federal spending cuts and tariff concerns take a toll on the economy. The future of solar power remains unclear amid a shift to clean energy, while robotics and innovation sectors face risks. Overall, the state's economic landscape is threatened by a dynamic policy environment and ideological divisions.

stories.headline: A minefield for Harvard, inside court — and out
stories.summary: Harvard University faces ongoing challenges due to legal battles stemming from the Trump administration's policies. While early wins have been secured, the Supreme Court poses a different and potentially more difficult test. Harvard is dealing with legal attrition, financial costs, and the impact on students and scholars. The State Department’s processing of visa applications for potential Harvard students remains a concern amid broader political and security issues.

stories.headline: Data centers: power play or energy drain? Expansion to test limits of local electric markets
stories.summary: As AI and digital demands surge, data centers require massive electricity, raising questions about energy consumption and sustainability in Massachusetts. The state is considering the impact of expanding data centers and related infrastructure such as solar panels and wind turbines. Challenges include balancing economic growth with combating climate change and managing local electricity markets to prevent fossil fuel reliance.

stories.headline: Armed and blasé: Guns part of ordinary life in Western Mass.
stories.summary: In Western Massachusetts, particularly Beacon Hill, firearms are common and part of everyday culture for many residents despite the lack of typical gun infrastructure like stores and gas stations. The area has a high ratio of guns per capita. This cultural acceptance exists amid a broader national debate on gun ownership and control, highlighting differing regional attitudes toward firearms.

stories.headline: The champ's crusade
stories.summary: Indy's only boxing champion, Lamon Brewster, helps women find their power through boxing training and empowerment programs, highlighting his dedication to community upliftment.

stories.headline: Ethics legislation stalls in Springfield
stories.summary: Efforts to pass ethics legislation in the Illinois General Assembly have failed in the final hours of the spring session. Senate President Don Harmon attempted to push a measure that would have wiped clean a fine against his political campaign committee, generating bipartisan controversy and opposition. The bill was ultimately blocked, leading to criticism within the House Democratic caucus.

stories.headline: 'MAIN STREET OF AMERICA' TURNS 100
stories.summary: Route 66, often called 'The Main Street of America', celebrates its 100-year history. The article highlights its importance as a major highway connecting many states and time zones, and its cultural influence, including references in literature, music, and film. The road introduced Americans to vast landscapes, freedom, and adventure.

stories.headline: The high price of crop insurance
stories.summary: This story explores the challenges and high costs farmers in Illinois face when purchasing crop insurance. It outlines how only large farms and companies benefit from these policies, which do not equally cover all crops. The article features Ed Dubrick, a first-generation farmer who found navigating crop insurance complex and burdensome.

stories.headline: Cuomo's Contrition Has Faded Over Sex Harassment Scandal
stories.summary: Former Governor Andrew M. Cuomo is facing criticism for his handling of past sexual harassment allegations. Despite initial apologies and settlements, new claims and investigations have emerged suggesting ongoing issues with abuse of power and a toxic work culture. His family members, including his sister Madeline Cuomo, have voiced support for those affected and criticized his conduct.

stories.headline: Here’s Looking at Them
stories.summary: A photo essay featuring Sadie Sink, George Clooney, Audra McDonald, and Tony nominees who discuss their personal challenges. The story offers a glimpse into the lives of prominent artists and performers.

stories.headline: Rich Compensation for C.E.O.s
stories.summary: The story highlights how top executives are motivated by pay packages that can reach extreme levels, with rewards likened to absolute monarchs. The article explores the culture and economics behind executive compensation.

stories.headline: San Francisco Spruces Up
stories.summary: San Francisco has created a new park that attracts skateboarders and offers lessons for urban revitalization. The initiative is part of the city’s efforts to enhance outdoor recreational spaces.

stories.headline: Of Prayers and Apartments
stories.summary: A pastor is tending to his congregation by devoting time to affordable housing issues, which is a growing concern for many in Brooklyn’s Black community. His efforts represent the intersection of faith and social activism.

stories.headline: The Best in New York City
stories.summary: The issue features 100 top restaurants in New York City, highlighting small miracles and the finest dining experiences available in a city famous for its culinary diversity.

stories.headline: Thunder’s Six-Armed Monster
stories.summary: Oklahoma’s trio of basketball stars including Luguentz Dort, Alex Caruso, and Cason Wallace have been showcasing outstanding performances. They have earned recognition for their unique playing styles and team contributions.

stories.headline: Democrats Plot 2026, and 2028
stories.summary: Democratic Party strategists in South Carolina and New Hampshire are preparing for the upcoming 2026 midterm elections and 2028 presidential race. Political buzz is intensifying around potential candidates and campaign strategies in these key states.

stories.headline: Macron to Visit Greenland
stories.summary: President Emmanuel Macron of France plans a visit to Greenland to demonstrate Europe's interest in the Arctic amid geopolitical shifts. The trip aims to reinforce diplomatic ties and address regional issues.

stories.headline: All We Want Is a Loaf of Bread
stories.summary: As aid supplies diminish, desperate parents in Gaza struggle to feed their starving children amid ongoing conflict. International aid agencies and officials warn of a worsening humanitarian crisis requiring urgent attention and support.

stories.headline: Victory at the French Open
stories.summary: Coco Gauff beat Aryna Sabalenka, becoming the first American singles champion at the French Open since 2015. This marks a significant achievement in her tennis career and adds to the excitement of the tournament's conclusion.

stories.headline: They Left Their Babies for Dead. Now, Family Tree DNA Is Used to Arrest Them.
stories.summary: The discovery and arrest of suspects in cold cases have increasingly involved using Family Tree DNA databases. Detectives have used DNA from crime scenes compared to genetic genealogy data to identify perpetrators of long-unsolved crimes. This method has recently led to new charges against individuals previously unknown to authorities. However, it has also raised questions about privacy and ethics in law enforcement.

stories.headline: Trump Crypto Buyer Has China Party Link
stories.summary: The Trump White House has quietly extended access to China’s Communist Party members to its digital currency program, granting some members VIP access. One notable buyer was identified as a VIP member of China’s political consultative conference, raising concerns about insufficient vetting at the White House. The revelations come amid broader investigations into Trump’s financial and political activities.

stories.headline: A.I. on Campus: Casting Chatbot As Study Buddy
stories.summary: OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, is embedding its artificial intelligence tools in every facet of campus life to assist students and faculty. It plans to customize AI study bots for class-specific support, offer premium services for universities, and run marketing campaigns targeting students who have not used ChatGPT. Some universities have started adopting AI tools in academic settings as competition in the AI arms race escalates among tech giants and universities.

stories.headline: Before the flameout, the fuse was burning: The battles that shattered an alliance
stories.summary: A behind-the-scenes look at the Trump-Musk saga reveals tensions and clashes including Trump's impeachment, Musk's use of ketamine and political pressures that drove a wedge between the two. The article discusses White House concerns about Musk's behavior and the eventual breakdown of this alliance amid political and personal struggles.

stories.headline: Rampaging militants gain ground in West Africa
stories.summary: Al-Qaeda affiliate JNIM is turning into a center of Islamist insurgency in West Africa, pushing back government forces and expanding control among local Islamist militants in the region. JNIM, formed from a coalition of Islamist armed groups, is creating a proto-state stretching from western Mali to the borders of Benin, with growing military capacity and connections to global Islamist networks.

stories.headline: A WorldPride milestone in D.C.
stories.summary: People gather Saturday in the nation’s capital for the annual WorldPride parade, marking the city’s 50th anniversary of Pride celebrations. The parade featured a 1,000-foot rainbow flag, more than 300 crooners and a team of cheerleaders in a three-week festival celebrating the LGBTQ community.

stories.headline: D.C. apartments for the poor exceeding $1 million to build
stories.summary: Development costs in D.C. are leading to increased prices for affordable housing units, with some apartments costing over $1.3 million to build. This is resulting in fewer affordable units during a time of urgent need, with developers citing rising costs and regulatory burdens. The article highlights the impact on low-income neighborhoods and the challenges facing affordable housing development.

stories.headline: Glory for Gauff
stories.summary: Coco Gauff defeated Aryna Sabalenka in three sets to become the first American woman to win a French Open singles title since 2015. This victory marks a major milestone in Gauff's tennis career and is celebrated as a significant achievement in American sports.

stories.headline: Trump orders Guard into L.A. amid protests over ICE raids
stories.summary: President Donald Trump ordered the California National Guard to Los Angeles to intervene in protests against immigration sweeps. The move was condemned by California Governor Gavin Newsom, as local authorities expressed concern over the deployment's impact on protest management and law enforcement resources. The situation reflects heightened tensions over immigration enforcement and public response.

stories.headline: OAKMONT OPENS UP
stories.summary: Oakmont Country Club hosts the U.S. Open golf championship for the 125th edition and a record 10th time. Oakmont welcomes some of the greatest golfers worldwide to compete in one of golf's four major championships, with expanded coverage provided by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.

stories.headline: International student cuts pose risks to bottom lines
stories.summary: College consultant Scott White highlights the financial impact of declining international student enrollment on universities, exacerbated by recent threats to Chinese student visas, travel bans on several countries, and the Trump administration policies. These cuts may affect schools' finances and admissions strategies nationwide.

stories.headline: Bumpy budget battle brewing
stories.summary: Pennsylvania's legislature is deeply divided over key spending issues as the budget deadline approaches. The new federal administration's funding cuts to state programs, coupled with financial crises in mass transit and ongoing pandemic-related federal fund changes, have created tensions and uncertainty about balancing the budget effectively.

stories.headline: Mobilizing young Catholics a key goal
stories.summary: Bishop Mark Eckman, newly appointed head of the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh, is focusing on revitalizing the Catholic community by encouraging more young priests and increasing young Catholic participation. He aims to build on the legacy of Bishop David Zubik, who served for the past decade and recently retired.
